text: In 18 66 Albert Bierstadt debuted this painting to great attendance in New York City.
The exhibition was a theatrical experience.
There was seating for viewers in front of the painting,
dramatic lighting and an accompanying leaflet to guide an east coast resident's
eye over this impressive distant rocky mountain landscape.
Describing the storm, the leaflet read quote,
"The character of these masses of clouds,
wind tossed and big with thunder is something wonderful.
The idea of motion conveyed in them is skillfully represented.
They seem to surge and swirl before the site to roll over and
over in massive forms and rock to and fro like ships at sea low down.
They are of a dark lead color running into black.
While above they grow lighter and are tinted, tender gray to the left.
They become fleecy and white and the blue sky appears amid this clear atmosphere.
The two snow peaks rise above this storm, peaceful and calm and tinged by the sunlight, a rosy hue.
a solitary eagle is cleaving his way through the heavens in advance of the approaching storm.
Bierstadt, Like other 19th century painters of the American West cultivated a reputation as an adventurer.
He joined scientific expeditions across the continent to inform his paintings.
He even invited journalists to join him and report on the 1863 journey that informed this painting,
the write ups and resulting awe inspiring paintings perpetuated an
understanding of the American continents as untouched wilderness.
They were also often used to advocate for the US government's theft of land
and the displacement of native Americans living in these regions.
